posts.title: Editorial:        Anaemia is not a distant health statistic
posts.content: Editorial:        Anaemia is not a distant health statistic. It is one of the most pressing health problems in the country today, and it is silently weakening the foundation of our society. Nearly half of Bhutanese children under the age of five suffer from anaemia. A third of our adolescents and pregnant women are affected as well. These numbers are more than just figures on a health report—they represent children who are too tired to focus in school, mothers facing dangerous pregnancies, and families coping with the weight of poor health. If left unchecked, anaemia will undermine our human capital, our ability to learn, work, and build a stronger nation. https://kuenselonline.com/.../nation-cannot-thrive-on... #anaemia #editorial #Bhutan
posts.author: Kuensel

posts.title: Lifestyle:    In a world that constantly advertises, applauds, and sells consumption, acquisition...
posts.content: Lifestyle:    In a world that constantly advertises, applauds, and sells consumption, acquisition and growth at all costs, cultivating a mindset of gratitude is not only challenging but absolutely necessary for our well-being. Just as water is nature’s perfect answer to thirst, gratitude is the antidote to our incessant dissatisfaction and desire for more. https://kuenselonline.com/news/ask-mr-bhutan-5 #MrBhutan #lifestyle

posts.title: Editorial:      ? The government has discontinued the tourist airfare subsidy after six months, foll
posts.content: Editorial:      ? The government has discontinued the tourist airfare subsidy after six months, following the recommendation made by the Economic and Finance Committee of the National Assembly. The scheme, launched in November 2024, promised to boost arrivals during off-season months. The government had allocated Nu 49.5 million for the subsidy, of which Nu 38.59 million was utilised. A total of 6,203 tourists benefitted from subsidised fares during the period. https://kuenselonline.com/.../was-the-airfare-subsidy... #tourism #DoT #TCB #Bhutan

posts.title: Kuensel Editorial:     ’ For years, cleaning campaigns in Bhutan have been little more than a ritual
posts.description: . People came together with gloves and sacks, streets looked tidy for a day or two, and social media brimmed with photos of civic duty. But soon enough, drains filled again, footpaths grew ugly with doma stains, and bridges became dumping sites. The message “do not litter in the first place” was repeated endlessly, but it rarely stuck. Conscience, it seems, was not enough. https://kuenselonline.com/.../cameras-catch-what... #editorial #Bhutan

posts.title: Update: The stretch of road along the Phuentsholing–Samtse highway at Amochu, in front of STCBL, ...
posts.content: Update: The stretch of road along the Phuentsholing–Samtse highway at Amochu, in front of STCBL, has been in poor condition for months, causing problems for commuters. Light vehicles often get stuck or sustain damage on the potholes, forcing drivers to slow down or stop. Commuters say the issue occurs daily, and even when repairs are carried out, the patches are washed away the next day by rain and traffic. Drivers are suggesting that they be allowed to use alternative lane for their safety and convenience. #Bhutan #Kuensel #news #UpdateNews #phuentsholing #amochhu #roadsafety

posts.title: Kuensel Editorial: The government’s decision to rev...
posts.content: Kuensel Editorial: The government’s decision to revise taxation on alcohol and tobacco products is a long-overdue step in the fight against non-communicable diseases (NCDs). The country is losing 72 percent of its population to illnesses that are preventable—diseases linked not to fate, but to lifestyle choices and substances we willingly consume. Stronger taxes on harmful products is not just a revenue measure, it is an act of national self-preservation. https://kuenselonline.com/news/taxing-harm-to-save-lives #NCDs #taxing #editorial #Bhutan

posts.title: His Royal Highness Prince Jigyel Ugyen Wangchuck, son of His Majesty the Fourth Druk Gyalpo Jigme...
posts.content: His Royal Highness Prince Jigyel Ugyen Wangchuck, son of His Majesty the Fourth Druk Gyalpo Jigme Singye Wangchuck and Her Majesty the Queen Mother Ashi Dorji Wangmo Wangchuck, was today joined in marriage with Ugen Choden Namgyel, daughter of Mr. Singye Namgyel and Mrs. Tshering Lhamo. The Royal Wedding was held at Dechencholing Palace in Thimphu on 25 August 2025. The Royal Couple received the sacred blessings of His Majesty The King, His Majesty the Fourth Druk Gyalpo, and His Holiness the Je Khenpo. His Royal Highness is a graduate of St Peter’s College, University of Oxford, where he earned his degree, and holds an Executive MBA from INSEAD. His Royal Highness serves the Kingdom with distinction as President of the Bhutan Olympic Committee since 2009, Vice President of the Olympic Council of Asia, and a Member of the International Olympic Committee. His Majesty King Jigme Khesar Namgyel Wangchuck

posts.title: Kuensel Just in—Jaigaon Police have recovered Nu 200,000 belonging to two Bhutanese farmers from ...
posts.description: Kuensel Just in—Jaigaon Police have recovered Nu 200,000 belonging to two Bhutanese farmers from Tading, Samtse, who were duped in a currency exchange scam across the border. The money was handed over to the victims today. The incident occurred on Monday when the victims were lured by individuals claiming to exchange ngultrum for US dollars at a favorable rate. Acting on the suspects’ directions, the two travelled from Phuentsholing to the Barobisa toll plaza, boarding a Nganglam-bound bus. Upon meeting the suspects, they were led into a forest on foot for about 15 to 20 kilometres, where their money and belongings were reportedly robbed. The victims later reached Jaigaon and filed a complaint at the local police station. Four individuals are suspected to be involved in the case. “We have got the money back and are thankful to Jaigaon Police IC Paljor Bhutia for helping us from the beginning,” one of the victims said. The victims, who had planned to travel abroad soon, said they were fortunate to have escaped unharmed and urged others to be cautious against similar scams.

posts.title: Kuensel October 8, 2025: As the third group of volunteers begin their work in Gelephu Mindfulness...
posts.description: Kuensel October 8, 2025: As the third group of volunteers begin their work in Gelephu Mindfulness City (GMC) His Majesty The King announced the launch of Pelsung. Pelsung, meaning Guardians of Prosperity, is a new national initiative to engage Bhutanese youth in developing creative and practical solutions for the GMC. His Majesty announced Pelsung as the third pillar of nation-building alongside Desuung and Gyalsung, instituted to help build strong foundations for the country’s future. “For a small population, every single person matters, and these programmes are intended to empower our people, to build harmony and the capacity to work together. As His Majesty the Fourth Druk Gyalpo said in the 1974 Coronation Address, our collective efforts will have far greater impact than the concerted efforts of a few,” His Majesty said. His Majesty said that the Gelephu Mindfulness City represents the aspirations of the nation taking shape, and that the sacred responsibility to protect Bhutan’s unity, harmony, and unique identity for all time falls on the youth. “Everything we are doing today is for our youth – so that they will be better versions of us, better prepared, smarter, and more hard-working. It falls on us to build that future, and on them to protect it and take it to greater heights,” His Majesty said. “That is the reason Pelsung has been created. I invite larger and larger numbers — the brightest and strongest amongst us — to join. We begin with 300–400 Pelsups, but expect to have thousands in the coming years. While today we bring in experts to help build the GMC, it is imperative that Bhutanese are able to take over the responsibility and become its custodians.” “My father entrusted the responsibility of Kingship to me when I was only 26, with enormous confidence and even greater expectations. I would

posts.title: Kuensel Thousands of volunteers from across the country are taking part in the third phase of the...
posts.description: Kuensel Thousands of volunteers from across the country are taking part in the third phase of the voluntary service in the Gelephu Mindfulness City (GMC). His Majesty the King graced the inauguration, along with the launch of the Innovate for GMC initiative. The former Yangbi Lopen of Zhung Dratshang, 98-year-old Baso Karp from Haa, is among 8,042 volunteers from Thimphu, Haa, Paro, Punakha and Mongar, along with trainees and locals from Sarpang, taking part in the third phase. For five days, starting today, citizens from all walks of life, including farmers, civil servants, monks, nuns, armed forces, Desuups, Gyalsuups, and parliamentarians, will set aside their daily routines to take up sickles and spades for bush clearance and the development of park areas and soft landscaping. +6

posts.title: October 6, 2025: Her Majesty The Gyaltsuen graced the inaugural session of the Third Annual PEMA ...
posts.description: October 6, 2025: Her Majesty The Gyaltsuen graced the inaugural session of the Third Annual PEMA Symposium at Zhichenkhar, Thimphu, this morning. Mental health experts and advocates from Bhutan and across the world have gathered in Thimphu for the three-day symposium, being held under the theme “Empowering Young Minds, Building Futures: Investing in Children and Adolescents’ Mental Health and Well-Being.” Addressing the Symposium, Her Majesty The Gyaltsuen spoke about our collective responsibility to nurture the wellbeing of our children. “No matter how much progress we make in education, health, or development, we cannot flourish as a society if our children do not feel safe, supported, and able to grow with confidence and joy,” Her Majesty said. Outlining important progress made since the establishment of the PEMA Secretariat three years ago, Her Majesty said that this was only the beginning. “Our children deserve a system that not only responds to harm but also actively promotes well-being, nurtures resilience, and prevents harm before it occurs. They deserve homes and schools where they feel safe, loved, and supported; communities that hear their voices and empower them to thrive; and services that are sensitive to their needs,” Her Majesty said. Her Majesty said that our Kings have always guided us through visionary policies, such as Gross National Happiness placing well-being and happiness as a measure of progress, and DeSuung, Gyalsung, and now GMC as avenues for young people to gain discipline, skills, purpose, and opportunities. The Prime Minister, Ministers, senior government officials, and representatives from stakeholder agencies, international organizations, civil society, and education institutions were part of the event. The Annual PEMA Symposium, initiated under the leadership of Her Majesty The Gyaltsuen, serves as a national platform to strengthen collaboration and advance mental health and well-being in Bhutan. This year’s symposium focuses on promoting the mental health of children and adolescents and strengthening systems within the health, education, and social sectors. The inaugural session also saw the launch of the National Mental Health Strategy and the Bhutan Reintegration and Value Enhancement (BRAVE) Programme, key initiatives to strengthen coordinated national action for mental health and well-being.

posts.title: Kuensel Gangtey Trulku Kunzang Rigdzin Pema Namgyal Rinpoche visited Pemaling in Serzhong on Octo...
posts.description: Kuensel Gangtey Trulku Kunzang Rigdzin Pema Namgyal Rinpoche visited Pemaling in Serzhong on October 3 to inspect the proposed site for the Kurkulee Centre under the Gelephu Mindfulness City (GMC). The GMC Governor, Dasho Dr Lotay Tshering, received Rinpoche, who was accompanied by the Kurkulee Centre Committee. The Centre, initiated by Gangtey Trulku Rinpoche, is one of eight spiritual projects approved by His Majesty the King in May this year, forming the spiritual foundation of the GMC and establishing it as a global hub for mindfulness and spiritual exploration. The project is envisioned as an iconic monument within the GMC that will embody sacred mandala geometry and enshrine the Kurkulee Tara statue. The main temple is expected to be completed within five years. Covering over 25 acres, Kurkulee Centre features the main temple, accommodation for monks and devotees, Dharma Centre/Chhoekhang, Healing Centre, Retreat Centre, Healing Garden, amphitheatre, sustainable organic farming, admin building, circulation/road network, open spaces, and parking facilities. Rinpoche expressed his deep gratitude to His Majesty the King for granting him and his Choetsog the sacred opportunity to participate in this noble national undertaking. During this auspicious occasion, prayers and aspirations were offered for the successful progress and swift completion of the Kurkulee Centre — a sacred project envisioned to fulfil His Majesty’s noble vision for the spiritual and social well-being of the people, according to the project office. To oversee the planning and execution of the project, the Kurkulee Centre Project Head Office was officially inaugurated on September 19, corresponding to the 28th day of the seventh month of the Female Wood Snake Year. Photos: Kurkulee Centre +5

Covering over 25 acres, Kurkulee Centre features the main temple, accommodation for monks and devotees, Dharma Centre/Chhoekhang, Healing Centre, Retreat Centre, Healing Garden, amphitheatre, sustainable organic farming, admin building, circulation/road network, open spaces, and parking facilities. Rinpoche expressed his deep gratitude to His Majesty the King for granting him and his Choetsog the sacred opportunity to participate in this noble national undertaking. During this auspicious occasion, prayers and aspirations were offered for the successful progress and swift completion of the Kurkulee Centre — a sacred project envisioned to fulfil His Majesty’s noble vision for the spiritual and social well-being of the people, according to the project office. To oversee the planning and execution of the project, the Kurkulee Centre Project Head Office was officially inaugurated on September 19, corresponding to the 28th day of the seventh month of the Female Wood Snake Year. Photos: Kurkulee Centre +5

Our educated youth and professionals are increasingly leaving for opportunities abroad, particularly Australia. posts.title: Kuensel Editorial:  ,     The Anti-Corruption Commission’s (ACC) recent investigation into the Pa...
posts.description: Kuensel Editorial:  ,     The Anti-Corruption Commission’s (ACC) recent investigation into the Paro Dzongkhag engineering cell has once again revealed how entrenched and systemic corruption can be when oversight is weak and personal interests override public duty. The case, implicating 27 individuals, including six public officials and 21 contractors, uncovered fraudulent bidding, bribery, and abuse of power in no fewer than 17 projects over six years. For a country that prides on being among the least corrupt in South Asia, the scale of collusion in this case is alarming. https://kuenselonline.com/.../fighting-corruption-both... #ACC #editorial #Bhutan

posts.title: Editorial:    At one point, “narrowing the gap” was a national mantra of sorts, fervently chanted...
posts.description: Editorial:    At one point, “narrowing the gap” was a national mantra of sorts, fervently chanted by our political leaders. A few years down the line, this national pursuit has quietly taken a backseat. Yet, inequalities are becoming increasingly evident between regions, income groups, and opportunities. The gap is evident in access to education, health, digital connectivity, employment, and regional development, among others. https://kuenselonline.com/news/bridging-the-gap-1 #editorial #Bhutan

posts.title: Kuensel Update: After arriving in New York for the UNGA High-Level Week, the Prime Minister began...
posts.description: Kuensel Update: After arriving in New York for the UNGA High-Level Week, the Prime Minister began his engagements with a meeting with Anna Bjerde, Managing Director of Operations at the World Bank. Their discussions focused on the status of ongoing projects and explored opportunities to deepen collaboration beyond the existing partnership framework. In the afternoon, the Prime Minister attended the P3 (Public-Private Partnerships) Summit, an exclusive gathering of global leaders and CEOs designed to align government priorities with private sector investments. In his address, the Prime Minister spoke on the opportunities for investment in the Gelephu Mindfulness City (GMC), emphasizing that under His Majesty’s leadership, the GMC represents a government that is business-ready. Later in the evening, the Prime Minister traveled to Washington D.C., where he is scheduled to meet senior U.S. officials and representatives from the U.S. Chamber of Commerce to discuss bilateral cooperation and explore opportunities for business and investment. Source: PMoB

posts.title: Kuensel           Bhutan was honored with the Best Leading Heritage Destination award at the Sout...
posts.description: Kuensel           Bhutan was honored with the Best Leading Heritage Destination award at the South Asian Travel Awards 2025 in Colombo, where over 1,500 participants from Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, Nepal, and Sri Lanka gathered to celebrate excellence in travel and hospitality. The Hotel and Restaurant Association of Bhutan (HRAB) received this prestigious award on behalf of the country, highlighting Bhutan’s commitment to preserving its cultural heritage. Among other Bhutanese winners, Zhiwaling Heritage received two awards—a Gold for Heritage Hotel and a Silver for Leading Eco-Friendly Resort. Le Méridien Paro Riverfront secured Gold in its category, while Druk Hotel and Darlha Hotel were recognized as leading city hotels above and below 40 rooms, respectively. Terma Linca Resort won two awards in Leading Spa & Wellness and conference & meeting Mr. Khagendra Dahal from Hotel Tashi YiD Wong Grand Hotel received the Best General Manager award. SATA appointed Kuenzang Thinley, Vice Chairman of HRAB, as SATA Bhutan Chapter Chairman. He will promote SATA’s vision, engage with local tourism stakeholders, encourage nominations, and serve as the official media spokesperson in Bhutan. This achievement highlights Bhutan’s growing prominence in South Asia’s travel industry. #Bhutan #heritage #AwardWinning #Kuensel +2

posts.title: Kuensel Actress Tandin Bidha won the Yakushi Pearl Award for her performance in "I, the Song" at ...
posts.description: Kuensel Actress Tandin Bidha won the Yakushi Pearl Award for her performance in "I, the Song" at the Osaka Asian Film Festival in Japan today. The award recognizes the most brilliant performers among all participating films cast members. "I, the Song" was selected in the competition category of this years Osaka Asian Film Festival. This is the second international award won by "I, the Song". The director of the film, Dechen Roder, won the Best Director Award for the film at the 28th Tallinn Black Nights Film Festival 2024 in Estonia, competing in the Critics' Picks Competition. The film is also the winner of multiple national awards at the Bhutan National Film Awards 2025, including Best Film. 0:00 / 2:01

posts.description: Drukpa Kuenga ༄༅། ། ཕ་བླ་ན་མེད་པ་རྗེ་བླ་མ། །ལྷ་བླ་ན་མེད་པ་སྤྱན་རས་གཟིགས། །ཆོས་བླ་ན་མེད་པ་ཡི་གེ་དྲུག །ཐུགས་བླ་ན་མེད་པ་བྱང་ཆུབ་སེམས། །མ་འགྲོ་དྲུག་ཀུན་གྱིས་ཐོབ་པར་ཤོག །འཕགས་པ་ཐུགས་རྗེ་ཆེན་པོ་སྤྱན་རས་གཟིགས་དང་གཉིས་སུ་མེད་པའི་དོན་བརྒྱུད་དཔལ་ལྡན་འབྲུག་པའི་རྒྱལ་ཡོངས་ཆོས་ཀྱི་དབུ་ཁྲིད་དམ་པ་ རྗེ་མཁན་ཁྲི་རབས་ ༧༠ པ་ དཔལ་འཇིགས་མེད་ཆོས་ཀྱི་གྲགས་པ་མཆོག་གི་སྤྲུལ་པའི་སྐུ་ སྐུ་ཚེ་འཆི་མེད་མགོན་པོ་ཚེ་ལྷ་རྣམ་གསུམ་གྱི་བརྟནད་ཅིང་ འགྲོ་དོན་འཕྲིན་ལས་འཕགས་པ་མིག་མི་ཟུམ་པ་དང་མཉམ་པར་ཤོག་ཅིག། ཅེས་པ་གང་གི་འབངས་མཐར་འཁོད་པ་འདུ་ཤེས་གསུམ་པ་དགེ་འདུན་དཔལ་བཟང་ངམ་ སངྒ་ཤྲཱི་བྷ་བས་སྨོན་པ་དགེའོ།། 3

posts.title: Kuensel 4 September 2025: His Majesty The King joined 7,050 volunteers contributing zhabtog (comm...
posts.description: Kuensel 4 September 2025: His Majesty The King joined 7,050 volunteers contributing zhabtog (community service) to develop public spaces and parks across Gelephu Mindfulness City A total of 7,050 volunteers are taking part in the program, including residents of Gelephu and nearby areas, Gyalsups and Desuups. Volunteers from outside Gelephu include Members of Parliament, various agencies, DHI and its companies, Bhutan Red Cross, Judiciary, NGOs, and community groups from Tsirang, Dagana, Pemathang, Phuentsholing, Trong, Mendrelgang, and Nganglam. The mass volunteer program, being held from 4-8 September, was developed following overwhelming interest from people across the country to participate in building GMC. They will work under expert coordinators to clean and clear areas identified for parks, install benches, water points and toilets, and beautify various parts of the GMC. His Majesty thanked the volunteers for their service in helping to build GMC, which represents the collective aspiration of the people of Bhutan to create a lasting legacy that will benefit generations into the future. +4
